head.title: U.S. Must Lead to Curb Global Warming

hedline.hl1: U.S. Must Lead to Curb Global Warming

block.p: "Nations to Consider Toughening Curbs on Global Warming" (Science Times, Feb. 21), on the coming Berlin climate summit, notes that global temperatures and public concern with global warming have dipped in the past three years.

"Nations to Consider Toughening Curbs on Global Warming" (Science Times, Feb. 21), on the coming Berlin climate summit, notes that global temperatures and public concern with global warming have dipped in the past three years.

You fail to note that the temporary cooling was attributable to the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines. Now that the volcano's cooling dusts have dispersed, global temperatures are rising exactly as climate modelers predicted.

You also note that at the United Nations climate talks last week, oil-producing countries and China opposed stronger measures such as the United States proposal to negotiate, by 1997, a "new aim" for reducing greenhouse gas emissions through 2020. But you fail to mention that the most vociferous opponents, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, are deploying extraordinary diplomatic tactics to block all collective measures by more forward-thinking nations.

Further, on key occasions at the climate talks, the United States remained silent in the face of this opposition. As the days slip by toward the April summit, the willingness of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to thumb their noses at their Persian Gulf war benefactor is disturbing -- as is the apparent American willingness to let them. ANNIE PETSONK International Counsel Environmental Defense Fund Washington, Feb. 23, 1995
